attributes.title: Project ENHANCE
attributes.description: Project ENHANCE: Assessing Professional Learning Needs for Ci3T

summary.value:
Project ENHANCE: Assessing Professional Learning Needs for Ci3T
Note. This project contains a preregistration in the attached file.

Statement of the Problem:
The Comprehensive, Integrated, Three-Tiered (Ci3T) model of prevention was designed to provide a systems approach for schools to address students’ academic, behavioral, and social needs in one coordinated model (Lane, Oakes, Cantwell, & Royer, 2016; McIntosh & Goodman, 2016). Specifically, the Ci3T model blends the principles of response to intervention (RTI; D. Fuchs, Fuchs, & Compton, 2012; focused primarily on academic domains), positive behavioral interventions and supports (PBIS; Sugai & Horner, 2009; focused primarily on behavioral domains), along with a validated social skills program such as Positive Action (Flay, Allred, & Ordway, 2001) focused on developing students’ social skill sets. Ci3T offers a comprehensive, integrated, data-driven prevention model with structures for monitoring system- and student-level data to determine effectiveness in meeting system/school goals and to inform instruction for students. In the Ci3T model, school-site leadership teams examine multiple sources of data to inform decision making - student performance measures are analyzed in conjunction with treatment integrity and social validity data. We know that MTSS is a complex, system-level model that requires effective collaboration among a variety of school-based professionals (e.g., administrators, special and general educators) and coordinated service delivery across multiple domains (e.g., academic, behavioral, social skills). Through our Ci3T partnership work, and in related work to develop online training to use behavior assessments (e.g. Chafouleas, Riley-Tillman, Jaffery, Miller, & Harrison, 2015; Crovello, Chafouleas, Volk, & Johnson, 2017), we have learned that school teams and teachers would benefit from on-demand professional learning resources to synthesize and make systematic decisions in applying data gathered to intervention decision making. As part of Project ENHANCE, we aim to develop on-demand modules to assist Ci3T leadership teams with professional learning necessary to function effectively and efficiently. We propose to develop Ci3T Building Capacity modules to reach a wide range of stakeholders on a variety of critical topics such as rationale for positive reinforcement, concerns regarding intrinsic motivation, installation of social-emotional curriculum at Tier 1, low-intensity strategies to increase engagement and decrease disruption, and data-based problem-solving.

attributes.title: The neurophysiological properties of the heartbeat evoked potential in health and disease: A systematic review protocol
attributes.description: A systematic review protocol of the neurophysiological properties underlying HEPs in both diagnostic conditions and healthy controls.

summary.value:
The heartbeat evoked potential (HEP) reflects the cortical processing of the heartbeat and is considered a marker of interoceptive function. Broadly speaking, greater HEP amplitude is thought to reflect better interoceptive performance. Interoceptive dysfunction has been implicated in various psychopathologies and clinical conditions, but significant gaps exist in our understanding of the current evidence concerning these implications. 

Given the developing field of research regarding HEPs within various populations, this systematic review will provide a comprehensive synthesis of the neurophysiological properties of HEPs in various groups. The literature review will identify the strengths and limitations of the studies that have provided primary data on HEPs, and by extension, identify any existing gaps in the literature to inform further research on HEP as a useful biomarker of interoception.

attributes.title: Understanding the role of trauma on social decision-making and trust

q1.value: Understanding the role of trauma on social decision-making and trust

q2.value: Jaye Jungmin Ahn, Iris Vilares, Fanshu Sun, Cristina Chuong

q3.value:
Betrayal trauma is when trauma is elicited by a close other (e.g. childhood sexual abuse, physical abuse) resulting in long-term social cognitive consequences that can obstruct an individuals’ ability to make choices about who to trust (Gobin & Freyd, 2014). Existing literature has demonstrated that early experiences of trauma influence an individuals’ ability to establish healthy interpersonal relationships because of individuals’ lack of trust in others. Research on revictimization of individuals in repeated traumatic events have shown that initial traumatic breaches of trust disrupts individual’s ability to differentiate risks of social situations and make proper decisions to trust others (Gobin & Freyd, 2009). Overall, research has suggested that traumatic events play a critical role in shaping an individual’s ability to trust others (and more specifically, make correct decisions on whom to trust). Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and borderline personality disorder (BPD) have both been examined in previous literature to predict reductions in trust in previous studies (Belli, Rogers, & Lau, 2012), however this relationship has not yet been found for betrayal trauma specifically. Considering the importance of trust on interpersonal relationships and recovery from trauma based on prior research, the relationship between trust and trauma must be further studied to gain a thorough understanding of the interaction between the two. 
The current study will utilize the trust game paradigm, an experimental behavioral economic game developed by Berg and McCabe (1995), to empirically analyze trust in an interpersonal setting. Results of previous studies have varied depending on the method of the project. Pitula and colleagues (2017) have found that children who have experienced significant traumas in the past display lower amounts of trust across different trials of the trust game. However, Gobin and Freyd (2014) did not find a significant relationship between betrayal trauma and trust behavior when they executed a similar study with adults. Furthermore, the observed effects on trust may depend on if the reciprocating partner is in a generous or betraying way (Pitula et al., 2017; Bell et al., 2019). These two studies differed not only in the population used (undergraduate psychology students vs. institutionalized adopted youth) but also in the number of trials used (one vs. multiple), and other methodological details. Many studies utilizing the trust game have additionally used computers as the other partner in the trust game, while deceiving participants that they were playing with actual people. This deception may be particularly relevant when studying trust, and in Gobin and Freyd’s study (2014) most participants did not believe they were playing with an actual partner. Due to the discrepancy between the methods of the trust game as well as the results of studies that examine this relationship, the present study focuses on analyzing the effect of betrayal trauma on trust in an undergraduate population sample, using both generous and betraying partners as well as no deception. Reciprocation patterns are predicted to be related to differential patterns of trust behavior based on the frequency of trauma one has experienced. There are three main research questions that arise from the study:

1.	To what extent does experience with trauma shape how individuals’ decide to trust others? Namely, we are interested in knowing:
1.1.	How does it affect individuals’ decision to trust others in an experimental trust game?
1.2.	How does it affect individuals’ expectations of the other’s behavior in an experimental trust game?
1.3.	How does it affect individuals’ belief about general trustworthiness?

2.	Does the effect of betrayal trauma on trust depend on the extent of the partner’s reciprocation of behaviors?

3.	How is betrayal trauma associated with the severity of borderline personality disorder (BPD) and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and does it mediate potential associations between BPD or PTSD and trust (or vice versa)?

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Trust and betrayal trauma are negatively correlated through a variety of behavioral and self-report measures.
Behavioral (exchanges in the trust game): Frequency of betrayal trauma (as measured by a higher score in the Brief Betrayal Trauma Survey; BBTS) will be negatively correlated with investment values during the trust game (initial investment, average investment in the first block, and average investment value) across all trials.

Self-report: Expectations of trust in the game: Frequency of betrayal trauma will be negatively correlated with self-reported expectations of the other player’s trustworthiness during the trust game (measured before, during, and after each block).

General trust beliefs: Frequency of betrayal trauma will be negatively correlated with individuals’ self-reported general beliefs about others’ honesty and trustworthiness, measured through the General Trust Scale.


Hypothesis 2: Betrayal trauma will differentially affect trust depending on the reciprocation of investments of either a betraying or generous partner.
Betrayal trauma is negatively correlated with the rate that participants increase their investments in the opposing player. 

Condition 1: Generous partner
Individuals with higher betrayal trauma, when compared with individuals with low betrayal trauma, will respond with slower increases in investments when playing with a generous partner who returns increasing values of investments.

Condition 2: Betraying partner:
Individuals with higher betrayal trauma will respond with faster decreases in investments when playing with a betraying partner who returns lower values, when compared with individuals with low betrayal trauma.


Hypothesis 3: Higher betrayal trauma will be associated with lower trust and with higher PTSD and/or BPD symptoms. Namely, we predict that:
There will be a positive correlation between betrayal trauma and PTSD and/or BPD symptoms.

Lower amounts of trust will be associated with greater severity of symptoms of PTSD and BPD, i.e. there will be a negative correlation between trust levels (both self-reports and behavior) and scores of PTSD and BPD screening instruments.

Trust behavior will act as a mediator between trauma levels and clinical symptoms.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value:
Participants will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact with the study subjects will not be aware of the subject’s betrayal trauma and other individual difference scores until the completion of the study.

question.value:
The present study is a between-subject design. Participants will be randomly assigned to play the trust game with one type of partner during each session. Participants will always play in the investor role while research assistants (RA) play as the trustee role. The investors start with up to $10 monetary units to exchange, while the trustee beings with $0. The two conditions include playing the game with either “generous” partner who increases the reciprocation amount per block, while a “betraying” partner decreases their reciprocation per block. For each condition, there will be four blocks of the game, each with 10 trials. A complete trial includes a back and forth interaction between the participant and research assistant exchanging monetary units. For each block, participants will complete five self-report questionnaires (once before the beginning of the trust game, and after each of the four blocks) to measure perceived trustworthiness of the partner as the blocks in the game advance. 

The partner they are playing with will be a RA from the lab. Participants will be aware of this (i.e. no deception), but will not meet the RA that is playing with them directly until the very end. A second RA will be available to explain the experiment, give instructions, and debrief the participant.

In block 1, the RA will return around 50% of the invested amount by the participant to establish a baseline trust. In block 2, the return amount will either increase or decrease 20% (with a 5% randomization across that value), and in block 3, the amount will further increase or decrease 10%, to establish the manipulation of a partner who does or does not reciprocate the original amount. Block 4 will repeat the rate of block 3. Results will analyze the behaviors of the participant within each block, as well as across all four blocks. These will be the contingencies:

Condition 1: “Generous partner”
Reciprocity: 
   45-55% (Block 1)  
   55-65% (Block 2)   
   65-75% (Block 3)   
   75-85% (Block 4)

Condition 2: “Betraying partner”
Reciprocity: 
   45-55% (Block 1)
   35-45% (Block 2)
   25-35% (Block 3)
   15-25% (Block 4)

Furthermore, at the end of the experiment, participants will be asked if they believed their game partner was played by a real person or a computer simulation. In addition, they will answer four different questionnaires measures (General Trust Scale; Brief Betrayal Trauma Survey, PTSD Checklist – Civilian Version, MacLean Screening Instrument).

q9.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to an experimental condition to either play with a “generous” or “betraying” participant during the trust game. 

After completion of the trust game, participants will answer four different questionnaires measures (General Trust Scale; Brief Betrayal Trauma Survey, PTSD Checklist – Civilian Version, MacLean Screening Instrument). The order of the presentation for each questionnaire will be randomized for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Individuals must be at least 18 years old and fluent in English to be eligible to participate. Participants will be from a population of undergraduate students recruited through the Research Experience Program, which rewards students with extra credit class points in exchange for their participation in research. Additionally, participants will earn and exchange points during the trust game, and these points will be converted to drawing tickets, for a chance to win a $100 Amazon gift card at the end of the study. The total amount of monetary units that the participant won from a session of the trust game will be divided by 4 and entered into the lottery to win $100. The winner will be contacted through email, which will be de-identified and separate from their data.

question.value: The target sample size is 190 participants. To consider for possible exclusions or missing data, we will attempt to recruit up to 230. In addition, because this will be based on a college sample population we will recruit participants until the end of the Spring 2020 term, hence the total number of participants recruited may differ slightly from the target sample size.

q13.value: The target sample size is 190 participants. To consider for possible exclusions or missing data, we will attempt to recruit up to 230. In addition, because this will be based on a college sample population we will recruit participants until the end of the Spring 2020 term, hence the total number of participants recruited may differ slightly from the target sample size.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a correlational power analysis. Our goal was to obtain 0.8 power to detect a medium correlation effect size of 0.2, one-tailed, at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability. This gives us a sample size of 95. As we will have two groups (one with the generous and one with the betraying partner), we will need twice the amount of participants, i.e. 190.

q15.value: We will run participants until the goal of 190 participants is met or until the end of the Spring Semester (May 2020), whichever comes later.

question.value:
Behavioral measure of trust – trust game: The measured variable will be participant’s behaviors during the trust game. Participants will play with either a generous or betraying partner, and asked to invest a certain amount of digital currency (monetary units) towards the other partner for over 20 trials. Variables measured from the trust game include the average invested monetary units across the trials, the average investment in the first block, the initial investment amount at the beginning of each block, and the change in average investment between each block. 

Self-report measures of trust: At the beginning and end of the experiment, and also between each block, participants will be asked about their perceived level of trust in specifically the other player (see below for details), serving as further dependent variables as a result of the trust game. 
Questions to measure the participant’s perceived trustworthiness in the other player are listed below, these questions will be asked intermittently during one block of the trust game on a 7 point Likert scale.
1.	How trustworthy do you rate the other participant as of now?
2.	How trustworthy do you rate the other participant to be in future trials?

In addition, the General Trust Scale will be used to measure participant’s global beliefs about other’s honesty and trustworthiness at a general level beyond the interaction with the other player. 

Questionnaires: Results from the Brief Betrayal Trauma Survey, the PTSD Checklist-Civilian Version, General Trust Scale, and the MacLean Screening Instrument for Borderline Personality Disorder will be completed by participants and scored.

Hypothesis 1: Trust and betrayal trauma are negatively correlated through a variety of behavioral and self-report measures

We will use a Spearman’s correlational test to analyze the relationship between the results of the trust game and scores from the Brief Betrayal Trauma index. The different correlation tests will examine the following relationships:
    Correlation between the average investment across trials for each condition and the betrayal trauma score
    Correlation between the initial investment per block with the betrayal trauma score
    Correlation between the average investment in the first block and betrayal trauma score
    Correlation between average scores from the General Trust Scale and betrayal trauma scores
    Correlation between average scores from the self-reported beliefs about the player’s trustworthiness and betrayal trauma scores
    These correlational tests will be compared between condition 1 and condition 2


Hypothesis 2: Betrayal trauma will differentially affect trust depending on the reciprocation of investments of either a betraying or generous partner

    Individuals with higher betrayal trauma will respond with faster decreases in investments when playing with a betraying partner who returns lower values, when compared with individuals with low betrayal trauma.
    We will use a Spearman’s correlational test to analyze the relationship between trauma level and changes in trust behavior across trials. The change in the investment (calculated through the slope of investment amounts) will be correlated with the scores from the BTTS. This calculation analysis will occur 


Hypothesis 3: Higher betrayal trauma will be associated with lower trust and with higher PTSD and/or BPD symptoms. Namely, we predict that:
    A mediation analysis (Baron & Kenny, 1986) will be conducted as a secondary analysis to determine how trust variables measured from the trust game mediates and predicts the relationship between trauma and PTSD (based on the PTSD Checklist) and Borderline Personality Disorder symptoms (MacLean Screening). 

In addition, we will look at the correlations between the behavioral trust measures, the self-reported beliefs in the trustworthiness of the partner, and the scores in the general trust scale (the expectation is that these correlations will be positive).

q21.value: We will use a one-tailed test for the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the correlational test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. Multiple comparisons will be corrected for when necessary.

q22.value:
Participants who are not at least 18 years old and/or not fluent in English will be excluded. Individuals who do not pass 70% of the attention checks during the survey will be excluded from the analyses. 

Finally, participants may be excluded from the analysis comparing the two types of reciprocating partners if they didn't experience reciprocation rates within 20% of the target rate (e.g. if participants, within a block, didn’t invest something in at least 20% of the trials).

q23.value: Participants who withdraw from the study will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value:
Participants will also be asked at the end of the study if they believed their game partner was played by a real person or a computer simulation. We may analyze separately the results of the participants that believed they were playing a real person vs. the ones that believed they were playing with a computer simulation.

We expect that demographic data may influence certain relationships found in the data. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (age, gender, ethnicity) and the primary outcome measures of trust behavior.

registration_responses.q8.question:
The present study is a between-subject design. Participants will be randomly assigned to play the trust game with one type of partner during each session. Participants will always play in the investor role while research assistants (RA) play as the trustee role. The investors start with up to $10 monetary units to exchange, while the trustee beings with $0. The two conditions include playing the game with either “generous” partner who increases the reciprocation amount per block, while a “betraying” partner decreases their reciprocation per block. For each condition, there will be four blocks of the game, each with 10 trials. A complete trial includes a back and forth interaction between the participant and research assistant exchanging monetary units. For each block, participants will complete five self-report questionnaires (once before the beginning of the trust game, and after each of the four blocks) to measure perceived trustworthiness of the partner as the blocks in the game advance. 

The partner they are playing with will be a RA from the lab. Participants will be aware of this (i.e. no deception), but will not meet the RA that is playing with them directly until the very end. A second RA will be available to explain the experiment, give instructions, and debrief the participant.

In block 1, the RA will return around 50% of the invested amount by the participant to establish a baseline trust. In block 2, the return amount will either increase or decrease 20% (with a 5% randomization across that value), and in block 3, the amount will further increase or decrease 10%, to establish the manipulation of a partner who does or does not reciprocate the original amount. Block 4 will repeat the rate of block 3. Results will analyze the behaviors of the participant within each block, as well as across all four blocks. These will be the contingencies:

Condition 1: “Generous partner”
Reciprocity: 
   45-55% (Block 1)  
   55-65% (Block 2)   
   65-75% (Block 3)   
   75-85% (Block 4)

Condition 2: “Betraying partner”
Reciprocity: 
   45-55% (Block 1)
   35-45% (Block 2)
   25-35% (Block 3)
   15-25% (Block 4)

Furthermore, at the end of the experiment, participants will be asked if they believed their game partner was played by a real person or a computer simulation. In addition, they will answer four different questionnaires measures (General Trust Scale; Brief Betrayal Trauma Survey, PTSD Checklist – Civilian Version, MacLean Screening Instrument).
registration_responses.q12.question: The target sample size is 190 participants. To consider for possible exclusions or missing data, we will attempt to recruit up to 230. In addition, because this will be based on a college sample population we will recruit participants until the end of the Spring 2020 term, hence the total number of participants recruited may differ slightly from the target sample size.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Behavioral measure of trust – trust game: The measured variable will be participant’s behaviors during the trust game. Participants will play with either a generous or betraying partner, and asked to invest a certain amount of digital currency (monetary units) towards the other partner for over 20 trials. Variables measured from the trust game include the average invested monetary units across the trials, the average investment in the first block, the initial investment amount at the beginning of each block, and the change in average investment between each block. 

Self-report measures of trust: At the beginning and end of the experiment, and also between each block, participants will be asked about their perceived level of trust in specifically the other player (see below for details), serving as further dependent variables as a result of the trust game. 
Questions to measure the participant’s perceived trustworthiness in the other player are listed below, these questions will be asked intermittently during one block of the trust game on a 7 point Likert scale.
1.	How trustworthy do you rate the other participant as of now?
2.	How trustworthy do you rate the other participant to be in future trials?

In addition, the General Trust Scale will be used to measure participant’s global beliefs about other’s honesty and trustworthiness at a general level beyond the interaction with the other player. 

Questionnaires: Results from the Brief Betrayal Trauma Survey, the PTSD Checklist-Civilian Version, General Trust Scale, and the MacLean Screening Instrument for Borderline Personality Disorder will be completed by participants and scored.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Hypothesis 1: Trust and betrayal trauma are negatively correlated through a variety of behavioral and self-report measures

We will use a Spearman’s correlational test to analyze the relationship between the results of the trust game and scores from the Brief Betrayal Trauma index. The different correlation tests will examine the following relationships:
    Correlation between the average investment across trials for each condition and the betrayal trauma score
    Correlation between the initial investment per block with the betrayal trauma score
    Correlation between the average investment in the first block and betrayal trauma score
    Correlation between average scores from the General Trust Scale and betrayal trauma scores
    Correlation between average scores from the self-reported beliefs about the player’s trustworthiness and betrayal trauma scores
    These correlational tests will be compared between condition 1 and condition 2


Hypothesis 2: Betrayal trauma will differentially affect trust depending on the reciprocation of investments of either a betraying or generous partner

    Individuals with higher betrayal trauma will respond with faster decreases in investments when playing with a betraying partner who returns lower values, when compared with individuals with low betrayal trauma.
    We will use a Spearman’s correlational test to analyze the relationship between trauma level and changes in trust behavior across trials. The change in the investment (calculated through the slope of investment amounts) will be correlated with the scores from the BTTS. This calculation analysis will occur 


Hypothesis 3: Higher betrayal trauma will be associated with lower trust and with higher PTSD and/or BPD symptoms. Namely, we predict that:
    A mediation analysis (Baron & Kenny, 1986) will be conducted as a secondary analysis to determine how trust variables measured from the trust game mediates and predicts the relationship between trauma and PTSD (based on the PTSD Checklist) and Borderline Personality Disorder symptoms (MacLean Screening). 

In addition, we will look at the correlations between the behavioral trust measures, the self-reported beliefs in the trustworthiness of the partner, and the scores in the general trust scale (the expectation is that these correlations will be positive).

q1.value: Biological age models as a tool in health promotion: a scoping review protocol

q2.value: Karina Louise Skov Husted, Jørn Wulff Helge, Pernille Hulst

q3.value: One challenge to overcome in health promotion is to provide clear feedback, with valuable individualized information, that could motivate to improve or sustain healthy lifestyle. Biological age as a health index for overall functional metabolic capacity and vulnerability to disease have potential on this matter. In order to recommend the use of biological age as a health index in health promotion of the general population a synthesis of the body of evidence currently available is needed. Therefore, we will perform a systematic scoping review aiming to answer the question: “what is known from the existing literature about the nature of biological age models to support health promotion initiatives?”

q4.value: As this is a scoping review we do not have any hypothesis.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Reviewers are blinded throughout the screening process in this systematic scoping review

question.value:
To make sure that the scoping review is conducted in a rigorous and transparent manner we follow the framework first developed by Arksey and O’Malley (Arksey & O'Malley, 2005) and later refined by Levac et al. (Levac, Colquhoun, & O'Brien, 2010) and the Joanna Briggs Institute (JBI, 2015; Peters et al., 2015). Thus, we organize the scoping review in five consecutive steps: 
1. Step: Identifying the research question.
2. Step: Identifying relevant studies.
3. Step: Study selection.
4. Step: Charting the data.
5. Step: Collating, summarizing, and reporting the results.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Based on the pilot search we agreed on the following inclusion criteria’s:
•	Type of publication: journal articles 
•	Time frame: any
•	Language: English
•	Population: adults, 18 years and above
•	Type of biological age model: Models aiming to prevent lifestyle related diseases (e.g. cardiovascular diseases, type 2 diabetes and chronic respiratory disease), obesity and metabolic syndrome. The biological age model can be referred as real age, fitness age, body age or similar. 

Based on the pilot search we agreed to exclude records on the following criteria’s:

•	Type of publication: books, conference abstracts, commentaries or editorials
•	Study objectives: Articles focusing on assessing variables as biomarkers without integrating them into a biological age model. 
•	Methods: biological age models including DNA, telomere or epigenetics and models derived from animals and in vitro models.

q13.value: As this is a systematic review I do not yet know how many records we will screen, nor the total number or articles included in the synthesis.

question.value: Not applicable for this review
We refer to the charting table showing the nine extraction fields.

A descriptive numerical analysis of the characteristics of included studies will be performed and presented in a Table. Thematic mapping will provide an overview of the variables included in biological age models. This outlines the applicability for using the biological age models in health promotion. We will depict the variation in disease and risk factors that biological age models target as well as how effectiveness is assessed using a graph.

q25.value: Read the uploaded "ScopingReviewProtocol" , Charting table and Flow chart for a full description of the protocol for the scoping review

attributes.title: Structure and Demographic Correlates of Individual Trait Responses to Emotions
attributes.description:
The purpose of this study is to determine the empirical relationships among trait responses to emotion (e.g., control, approach, escape, and avoidance) using a large, diverse sample. The first aim of this study is to develop a multidimensional model of the empirical relationships among trait responses to emotion to characterize their relationships. The second aim includes exploring the correlations between each individual’s dimension scores and demographic variables such as age, gender, early socioeconomic context (SEC), and early life experiences. 

AMENDMENT: Please note an error in wording in the Variables section, found on 2/25/20 at 4:27 pm EST, for the SEC variable. Rather than saying "We will then utilize publicly available data from Social Explorer, a website that provides access to United States census data, to look at county-specific demographic information (i.e., population, percent unemployed, median household income) to assess early life SEC", this section should say that "We will then utilize publicly available data from Social Explorer, a website that provides access to United States census data, to look at county-specific demographic information (i.e., percent unemployed, median household income, and education) to assess early life SEC" since education, not population, is necessary for analyzing SEC. This error in wording was found prior to any data analysis taking place.

q1.value: Structure and Demographic Correlates of Individual Trait Responses to Emotions

q3.value: The purpose of this study is to determine the empirical relationships among trait responses to emotion (e.g., control, approach, escape, and avoidance) using a large, diverse sample. The first aim of this study is to develop a multidimensional model of the empirical relationships among trait responses to emotion to characterize their relationships. The second aim includes exploring the correlations between each individual’s dimension scores and demographic variables such as age, gender, early socioeconomic context (SEC), and early life experiences.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Approach, avoidance, and control will characterize the dimensional structure of trait responses to emotion (i.e., approach vs. avoidance, control vs. dyscontrol).

Hypothesis 2: Individuals who are younger and are female will utilize more approach trait emotion responses; in contrast, individuals who are older and are male will utilize more avoidant trait emotion responses. Additionally, individuals who are older and are female (particularly in regard to negative emotions) will utilize more control trait emotion responses than individuals who are younger and are male (particularly in regard to negative emotions).

Hypothesis 3: There is less evidence for the effects of SEC and early life experiences on trait emotion responses; exploratory analyses of the relationships between these variables and dimensions of trait emotion responses will be conducted.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants will be recruited through a survey link posted on the TurkPrime website. On the first page of the survey, participants will be able to read the consent form that will include information about the tasks for the study, confidentiality, and compensation. They can give their consent to participate and will complete a web-based battery of surveys on TurkPrime. The order of the surveys will be the same for the first few measures, where participants will fill out their demographic information and then the early life socioeconomic context (SEC) measure. Then, the trait response to emotion and anchoring measures will be randomized by display order for each participant to prevent order effects.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The participants for the proposed study will be drawn from anonymous Mechanical Turk (MTurk) workers via an online survey posted to the MTurk website for one to two weeks. MTurk is a crowdsourcing website owned by Amazon that allows researchers and businesses to post surveys and tasks for users (known as MTurk workers) to complete for compensation. To avoid bots and “farmers”, we will be using TurkPrime, a free service from Amazon, similar to MTurk. MTurk workers are comprised of about 75% United States residents, about 40% are younger than 30, about 60% are female, about 70% have a Bachelor degree or higher, and about 60% have an annual income greater than $25,000/year (Ross et al., 2010). Additionally, about 75% of MTurk workers identify as white (Huff and Tingley, 2015). By nature of these demographics, there may be a slight skew toward more well-educated and higher income individuals. The survey’s availability will be limited to the United States to ensure results are applicable to and relatively representative of United States residents because we expect that the trait response to emotion dimensional structure could be different depending on one’s country of origin. Participants will be compensated $5 for completing the survey.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 250 participants. We will initially recruit 300 to account for attrition and/or missing data.

q14.value: Sample size will be determined to accurately estimate the correlations in our model rather than statistical significance. The sample size and stability of correlations is impacted by the reliability of the measures utilized in a study (Schönbrodt and Perugini, 2013). All measures' reliability in the sample will be measured using omega, which will provide us with a more accurate measure of reliability. Because the study will employ reliable measures and to account for attrition, target sample size will be 250. This sample size will bring our data to the “point of stability”, meaning that correlation estimates will be stable, allowing for more accurate estimation of “distance” among constructs (e.g., how similar or dissimilar constructs are to each other).

q15.value: We will post the survey link to TurkPrime with a designated upward limit of 300 responses. Once 300 responses have been collected, data will be reviewed to ensure that all responses are complete. If there are incomplete responses that bring our sample size below 250, the survey link will be reposted with a new designated upward limit until we recruit 250 complete responses.

question.value: N/A

Demographics: Participants will provide relevant demographic information such as their age, gender, SES, education, and race/ethnicity.

Early life SEC will be assessed via a single-item, open-ended question, which will ask participants, “What cities and states did you live in from ages 10-18 years old?” Participants will list what year, city, and state they lived in for each year of age (e.g., age 10, 11, 12) during that time frame; if they lived in multiple places in one year, participants will be asked to report where they lived for most of that year. We will then utilize publicly available data from Social Explorer, a website that provides access to United States census data, to look at county-specific demographic information (i.e., population, percent unemployed, median household income) to assess early life SEC (Scott et al., 2018).

Early life experiences will be assessed with the Risky Families Questionnaire (Felitti et al., 1998; Taylor, Lerner, Sage, Lehman, and Seeman, 2004). The Risky Families Questionnaire is a 13-item measure (10 items +3 filler items) that uses a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very often) to assess the degree of risk of physical, mental, and emotional distress experienced by participants in their homes during childhood and adolescence.

The control-related trait, urgency, will be assessed with the Positive Urgency Measure (PUR; Cyders et al., 2007) and Negative Urgency (NUR) scale of the revised version of the UPPS Impulsive Behavior Scale (UPPS-R; Whiteside and Lynam, 2001). The PUR is a 14-item measure that uses a 4-point Likert-type scale ranging from 1 (agree strongly) to 4 (disagree strongly) to assess urgency when experiencing positive emotions. The NUR is a 12-item subscale of the UPPS-R that also uses a 4-point Likert-type scale ranging from 1 (agree strongly) to 4 (disagree strongly) to assess urgency when experiencing negative emotions.

Approach- and avoidance-related traits will be assessed with the Need for Affect Scale (Maio and Esses, 2001), the Acceptance and Action Questionnaire-II (Bond et al., 2011), the Acceptance of Emotions Scale (Weihs, Enright, and Simmens, 2008), and the Emotional Approach Coping Scale (Stanton et al., 2000). 

The Need for Affect Scale is a 26-item measure that uses a 7-point response scale ranging from -3 (strongly disagree) to 3 (strongly agree) with 13 items that assess motivation to approach emotions and 13 items to assess the motivation to avoid emotions. 

The Acceptance and Action Questionnaire-II (AAQ-II) is a 7-item measure that uses a 7-point response scale ranging from 1 (never true) to 7 (always true) that assesses psychological inflexibility or experiential avoidance.

The Acceptance of Emotions Scale (AE) is a 13-item measure where responses are based on the percentage of time that each statement is true in increments of 10, ranging from 0 (never/not at all) to 100 (always/perfectly). It assesses the extent that individuals are accepting of their feelings, and higher scores indicate more emotional acceptance. 

Emotion Approach Coping (EAC) will be assessed with the dispositional version of the Emotional Approach Coping Scale (Stanton et al., 2000), which measures people’s characteristic ways of managing emotions in stressful encounters. The Emotional Approach Coping Scale is an 8-item measure that uses a 4-point response option ranging from 1 (I usually don’t do this at all) to 4 (I usually do this a lot) and measures two domains for coping through emotional approach: emotional processing and emotional expression.

Emotion expression will be assessed with the Berkeley Expressivity Questionnaire (Gross and John, 1998), the Emotional Expressiveness Questionnaire (King and Emmons, 1990), the Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (Gross and John, 2003), and the Affective Style Questionnaire (Hofmann and Kashdan, 2010). 

The Berkeley Expressivity Questionnaire is a 16-item measure that uses a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree) that assesses three facets of emotional expressivity: negative expressivity, positive expressivity, and impulse strength. 

The Emotional Expressiveness Questionnaire is a 16-item measure that uses a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (does not agree at all) to 7 (strongly agrees) that assesses the expression of positive and negative emotions and intimacy. High scores on the EEQ indicate higher emotion expression. 

The expressive suppression subscale of the Emotion Regulation Questionnaire is a 4-item measure that uses a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree) that assesses individual differences in expressive suppression. 

The Affective Style Questionnaire is a 20-item measure that uses a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (not true of me at all) to 5 (extremely true of me) that assesses individual differences in emotion regulation techniques. The scale includes three subscales: concealing, adjusting, and tolerating.

Alexithymia will be assessed with the Toronto Alexithymia Scale-II (Bagby, Parker, and Taylor, 1993). The Toronto Alexithymia Scale-II (TAS-20) is a 20-item measure that uses a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree) that assesses alexithymia. The scale includes three subscales: difficulty describing feelings, difficulty identifying feeling, and externally-oriented thinking.

Affectivity will be assessed with the modified Differential Emotions Scale (Fredrickson, Tugade, Waugh, and Larkin, 2003). The modified Differential Emotions Scale (mDES) is a 20-item measure that uses a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 0 (not at all) to 4 (extremely) to assess the degree and frequency of positive and negative emotions. The scale includes two subscales: positive emotions and negative emotions.

In order to assess whether our proposed dimensions represent approach/avoidance and control/dyscontrol, we will use the BIS/BAS Scale (Carver and White, 2013) and the Brief Self-Control Scale (Tangney, Baumeister, and Boone, 2004) as anchoring scales.

The BIS/BAS scale is a 24-item measure that uses a 4-point scale ranging from 1 (very true for me) to 4 (very false for me) to measure two motivational systems, the behavioral inhibition system (BIS) and the behavioral activation system (BAS). The BIS corresponds to motivation to avoid aversive outcomes, and the BAS corresponds to motivation to approach goal-oriented outcomes.

The Brief Self-Control Scale is a 13-item measure that uses a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (Not at all like me) to 5 (very much like me) to assess dispositional self-regulatory behaviors.

The mean of each trait response to emotion scale (i.e., ispative mean imputation) for each scale will be converted to a z score. Scales with more than 50% missing items will be considered missing for that person and not subject to further analysis. A general propensity to response to emotion will be assessed by examining item-total correlations and the mean correlation among the measures, and if there is evidence for a general propensity (majority of item-total correlations greater than .30), then the z scores will be summed. 

Dimension scores will be created by weighting z scores for each measure of response to emotion by its value on that dimension and summing. Anchoring scales will not be included in the dimension scores.

1.	Hypothesis 1 states that two dimensions (approach/avoidance and control/dyscontrol) will characterize the factor structure of trait responses to emotion. The multidimensional model will be constructed using ALSCAL in SPSS. Distances among emotion trait response measures and anchoring scales will be calculated as 1 minus the correlation between each pair of measures and treated as interval data. There are 19 total emotion trait response measures (including subscales), allowing up to 4-dimensional models (Kruskal and Wish, 1978). Stress statistics will be examined for 1- through 4-dimensional models, and the highest-dimensional model that yields a substantive reduction in stress (greater than or equal to .05) will be adopted. The position of anchoring scales (e.g., BIS/BAS Scales and the Brief Self-Control Scale) will be used to determine whether dimensions represent approach/avoidance and control; that is, if an anchoring scale lies along the dimension rather than in interstitial space, its construct will provide interpretation of the scale.

2.	Hypothesis 2 states that individuals who are younger and are female will utilize more approach trait emotion responses; in contrast, individuals who are older and are male will utilize more avoidant trait emotion responses. Additionally, individuals who are older and are female (particularly in regard to negative emotions) will utilize more control trait emotion responses than individuals who are younger and are male (particularly in regard to negative emotions).

The relationships among these demographic variables and the dimension scores will be investigated using both zero-order correlations and multiple regression models. Multiple regression models will allow for us to model the relationships between the demographic variables and the dimension scores by fitting a linear equation to observed data. Every demographic variable will serve as an independent variable, and the dimension score will be the dependent variable. The demographic variables’ relationship with the dimension score will be calculated while holding the other demographic variables constant using the following equation: (dimension score) = B_0 + B_1X_((age)) + B_2X_((gender)) where β0 = the predicted value of the dimension score when all demographic variables are held constant, and β_iX = the regression coefficient (or slope) for an independent variable. To determine statistical significance, alpha will be set at p is less than .05. The Benjamini-Hochberg procedure, a sequential approach that is equivalent to Bonferroni correction but has been demonstrated to yield greater power (Benjamini and Hochberg, 1995; Thissen, Steinberg, Kuang, 2002), will be applied to account for performing multiple tests on each proposed trait response to emotion dimension to reduce our Type I error rate.

q20.value: Descriptive statistics (e.g., means, standard deviations, skew, kurtosis, minimums, maximums, ranges, etc.) will be analyzed for all demographic and trait responses to emotion measures to investigate the distribution of the variables. Any significantly skewed (e.g., skewness is less than -1 or greater than 1) or kurtotic (e.g., kurtosis is less than -1 or greater than 1), variables will be transformed to approximate normal distributions, although our planned statistical analyses are robust to violations of statistical normality.

q21.value: Model fit will be assessed by stress values, which is a measure that is comparable to the square root of the residual sum of squares when the model is used to estimate the initial distance matrix. Stress values that are close to zero would indicate good model fit. We would be able to determine how many dimensions best represent the model for trait responses to emotion based on if the stress value continues to decrease with the addition of another dimension. If the stress value no longer decreases by at least .05 with the addition of dimensions past n, then we can determine that the current number of dimensions best represents the model for trait responses to emotion. Based on Kruskal’s guidelines, we are aiming for good model fit (e.g., .05 stress value), which will allow us to be able to look for dimensional characteristics of trait responses to emotion (Kruskal, 1964).

q22.value: If a participant has missing data for equal to or more than 75% of measures, their data will not be used in analyses. Throughout the battery of surveys, validation items are included (e.g., awareness checks) to check for random responding. If a participant responds in a nonsensical way (e.g., selecting anything but "disagree strongly" for a validation question like "I work for robots") for equal to or more than one validation question, their data will not be used in analyses. Outliers will be included in the analyses.

q23.value: Missing data will be handled on a case-by-case basis. For instance, if a participant is missing data for the majority of items on a measure (50% or more of the items are missing; Schafer and Graham, 2002), their total score for that measure will not be included in analyses. If a participant has missing data for equal to or more than 75% of measures, their data will not be used in analyses.

q24.value: Hypothesis 3: There is less evidence for the effects of SEC and early life experiences on trait emotion responses; exploratory analyses of the relationships between these variables and dimensions of trait emotion responses will be conducted using both zero-order correlations and multiple regression models. Multiple regression models will allow for us to model the relationships between the demographic variables and the dimension scores by fitting a linear equation to observed data. Every demographic variable will serve as an independent variable, and the dimension score will be the dependent variable. The demographic variables’ relationship with the dimension score will be calculated while holding the other demographic variables constant using the following equation: (dimension score) = B_0 + B_1X_((SEC)) + B_2X_((early life experiences)) where β0 = the predicted value of the dimension score when all demographic variables are held constant, and β_iX = the regression coefficient (or slope) for an independent variable. To determine statistical significance, alpha will be set at p is less than .05. The Benjamini-Hochberg procedure, a sequential approach that is equivalent to Bonferroni correction but has been demonstrated to yield greater power (Benjamini and Hochberg, 1995; Thissen, Steinberg, Kuang, 2002), will be applied to account for performing multiple tests on each proposed trait response to emotion dimension to reduce our Type I error rate.

registration_responses.q1: Structure and Demographic Correlates of Individual Trait Responses to Emotions
registration_responses.q3: The purpose of this study is to determine the empirical relationships among trait responses to emotion (e.g., control, approach, escape, and avoidance) using a large, diverse sample. The first aim of this study is to develop a multidimensional model of the empirical relationships among trait responses to emotion to characterize their relationships. The second aim includes exploring the correlations between each individual’s dimension scores and demographic variables such as age, gender, early socioeconomic context (SEC), and early life experiences.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1: Approach, avoidance, and control will characterize the dimensional structure of trait responses to emotion (i.e., approach vs. avoidance, control vs. dyscontrol).

Hypothesis 2: Individuals who are younger and are female will utilize more approach trait emotion responses; in contrast, individuals who are older and are male will utilize more avoidant trait emotion responses. Additionally, individuals who are older and are female (particularly in regard to negative emotions) will utilize more control trait emotion responses than individuals who are younger and are male (particularly in regard to negative emotions).

Hypothesis 3: There is less evidence for the effects of SEC and early life experiences on trait emotion responses; exploratory analyses of the relationships between these variables and dimensions of trait emotion responses will be conducted.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 250 participants. We will initially recruit 300 to account for attrition and/or missing data.
registration_responses.q14: Sample size will be determined to accurately estimate the correlations in our model rather than statistical significance. The sample size and stability of correlations is impacted by the reliability of the measures utilized in a study (Schönbrodt and Perugini, 2013). All measures' reliability in the sample will be measured using omega, which will provide us with a more accurate measure of reliability. Because the study will employ reliable measures and to account for attrition, target sample size will be 250. This sample size will bring our data to the “point of stability”, meaning that correlation estimates will be stable, allowing for more accurate estimation of “distance” among constructs (e.g., how similar or dissimilar constructs are to each other).
registration_responses.q15: We will post the survey link to TurkPrime with a designated upward limit of 300 responses. Once 300 responses have been collected, data will be reviewed to ensure that all responses are complete. If there are incomplete responses that bring our sample size below 250, the survey link will be reposted with a new designated upward limit until we recruit 250 complete responses.
registration_responses.q20: Descriptive statistics (e.g., means, standard deviations, skew, kurtosis, minimums, maximums, ranges, etc.) will be analyzed for all demographic and trait responses to emotion measures to investigate the distribution of the variables. Any significantly skewed (e.g., skewness is less than -1 or greater than 1) or kurtotic (e.g., kurtosis is less than -1 or greater than 1), variables will be transformed to approximate normal distributions, although our planned statistical analyses are robust to violations of statistical normality.
registration_responses.q21: Model fit will be assessed by stress values, which is a measure that is comparable to the square root of the residual sum of squares when the model is used to estimate the initial distance matrix. Stress values that are close to zero would indicate good model fit. We would be able to determine how many dimensions best represent the model for trait responses to emotion based on if the stress value continues to decrease with the addition of another dimension. If the stress value no longer decreases by at least .05 with the addition of dimensions past n, then we can determine that the current number of dimensions best represents the model for trait responses to emotion. Based on Kruskal’s guidelines, we are aiming for good model fit (e.g., .05 stress value), which will allow us to be able to look for dimensional characteristics of trait responses to emotion (Kruskal, 1964).
registration_responses.q22: If a participant has missing data for equal to or more than 75% of measures, their data will not be used in analyses. Throughout the battery of surveys, validation items are included (e.g., awareness checks) to check for random responding. If a participant responds in a nonsensical way (e.g., selecting anything but "disagree strongly" for a validation question like "I work for robots") for equal to or more than one validation question, their data will not be used in analyses. Outliers will be included in the analyses.
registration_responses.q23: Missing data will be handled on a case-by-case basis. For instance, if a participant is missing data for the majority of items on a measure (50% or more of the items are missing; Schafer and Graham, 2002), their total score for that measure will not be included in analyses. If a participant has missing data for equal to or more than 75% of measures, their data will not be used in analyses.
registration_responses.q24: Hypothesis 3: There is less evidence for the effects of SEC and early life experiences on trait emotion responses; exploratory analyses of the relationships between these variables and dimensions of trait emotion responses will be conducted using both zero-order correlations and multiple regression models. Multiple regression models will allow for us to model the relationships between the demographic variables and the dimension scores by fitting a linear equation to observed data. registration_responses.q8.question: Participants will be recruited through a survey link posted on the TurkPrime website. On the first page of the survey, participants will be able to read the consent form that will include information about the tasks for the study, confidentiality, and compensation. They can give their consent to participate and will complete a web-based battery of surveys on TurkPrime. The order of the surveys will be the same for the first few measures, where participants will fill out their demographic information and then the early life socioeconomic context (SEC) measure. Then, the trait response to emotion and anchoring measures will be randomized by display order for each participant to prevent order effects.
registration_responses.q12.question: The participants for the proposed study will be drawn from anonymous Mechanical Turk (MTurk) workers via an online survey posted to the MTurk website for one to two weeks. MTurk is a crowdsourcing website owned by Amazon that allows researchers and businesses to post surveys and tasks for users (known as MTurk workers) to complete for compensation. To avoid bots and “farmers”, we will be using TurkPrime, a free service from Amazon, similar to MTurk. MTurk workers are comprised of about 75% United States residents, about 40% are younger than 30, about 60% are female, about 70% have a Bachelor degree or higher, and about 60% have an annual income greater than $25,000/year (Ross et al., 2010). Additionally, about 75% of MTurk workers identify as white (Huff and Tingley, 2015). By nature of these demographics, there may be a slight skew toward more well-educated and higher income individuals. The survey’s availability will be limited to the United States to ensure results are applicable to and relatively representative of United States residents because we expect that the trait response to emotion dimensional structure could be different depending on one’s country of origin. Participants will be compensated $5 for completing the survey.
registration_responses.q16.question: N/A
registration_responses.q17.question:
Demographics: Participants will provide relevant demographic information such as their age, gender, SES, education, and race/ethnicity.

Early life SEC will be assessed via a single-item, open-ended question, which will ask participants, “What cities and states did you live in from ages 10-18 years old?” Participants will list what year, city, and state they lived in for each year of age (e.g., age 10, 11, 12) during that time frame; if they lived in multiple places in one year, participants will be asked to report where they lived for most of that year. We will then utilize publicly available data from Social Explorer, a website that provides access to United States census data, to look at county-specific demographic information (i.e., population, percent unemployed, median household income) to assess early life SEC (Scott et al., 2018).

Early life experiences will be assessed with the Risky Families Questionnaire (Felitti et al., 1998; Taylor, Lerner, Sage, Lehman, and Seeman, 2004). The Risky Families Questionnaire is a 13-item measure (10 items +3 filler items) that uses a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very often) to assess the degree of risk of physical, mental, and emotional distress experienced by participants in their homes during childhood and adolescence.

The control-related trait, urgency, will be assessed with the Positive Urgency Measure (PUR; Cyders et al., 2007) and Negative Urgency (NUR) scale of the revised version of the UPPS Impulsive Behavior Scale (UPPS-R; Whiteside and Lynam, 2001). The PUR is a 14-item measure that uses a 4-point Likert-type scale ranging from 1 (agree strongly) to 4 (disagree strongly) to assess urgency when experiencing positive emotions. The NUR is a 12-item subscale of the UPPS-R that also uses a 4-point Likert-type scale ranging from 1 (agree strongly) to 4 (disagree strongly) to assess urgency when experiencing negative emotions.

Approach- and avoidance-related traits will be assessed with the Need for Affect Scale (Maio and Esses, 2001), the Acceptance and Action Questionnaire-II (Bond et al., 2011), the Acceptance of Emotions Scale (Weihs, Enright, and Simmens, 2008), and the Emotional Approach Coping Scale (Stanton et al., 2000). 

The Need for Affect Scale is a 26-item measure that uses a 7-point response scale ranging from -3 (strongly disagree) to 3 (strongly agree) with 13 items that assess motivation to approach emotions and 13 items to assess the motivation to avoid emotions. 

The Acceptance and Action Questionnaire-II (AAQ-II) is a 7-item measure that uses a 7-point response scale ranging from 1 (never true) to 7 (always true) that assesses psychological inflexibility or experiential avoidance.

The Acceptance of Emotions Scale (AE) is a 13-item measure where responses are based on the percentage of time that each statement is true in increments of 10, ranging from 0 (never/not at all) to 100 (always/perfectly). It assesses the extent that individuals are accepting of their feelings, and higher scores indicate more emotional acceptance. 

Emotion Approach Coping (EAC) will be assessed with the dispositional version of the Emotional Approach Coping Scale (Stanton et al., 2000), which measures people’s characteristic ways of managing emotions in stressful encounters. The Emotional Approach Coping Scale is an 8-item measure that uses a 4-point response option ranging from 1 (I usually don’t do this at all) to 4 (I usually do this a lot) and measures two domains for coping through emotional approach: emotional processing and emotional expression.

Emotion expression will be assessed with the Berkeley Expressivity Questionnaire (Gross and John, 1998), the Emotional Expressiveness Questionnaire (King and Emmons, 1990), the Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (Gross and John, 2003), and the Affective Style Questionnaire (Hofmann and Kashdan, 2010). 

The Berkeley Expressivity Questionnaire is a 16-item measure that uses a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree) that assesses three facets of emotional expressivity: negative expressivity, positive expressivity, and impulse strength. 

The Emotional Expressiveness Questionnaire is a 16-item measure that uses a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (does not agree at all) to 7 (strongly agrees) that assesses the expression of positive and negative emotions and intimacy. High scores on the EEQ indicate higher emotion expression. 

The expressive suppression subscale of the Emotion Regulation Questionnaire is a 4-item measure that uses a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree) that assesses individual differences in expressive suppression. 

The Affective Style Questionnaire is a 20-item measure that uses a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (not true of me at all) to 5 (extremely true of me) that assesses individual differences in emotion regulation techniques. The scale includes three subscales: concealing, adjusting, and tolerating.

Alexithymia will be assessed with the Toronto Alexithymia Scale-II (Bagby, Parker, and Taylor, 1993). The Toronto Alexithymia Scale-II (TAS-20) is a 20-item measure that uses a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree) that assesses alexithymia. The scale includes three subscales: difficulty describing feelings, difficulty identifying feeling, and externally-oriented thinking.

Affectivity will be assessed with the modified Differential Emotions Scale (Fredrickson, Tugade, Waugh, and Larkin, 2003). The modified Differential Emotions Scale (mDES) is a 20-item measure that uses a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 0 (not at all) to 4 (extremely) to assess the degree and frequency of positive and negative emotions. The scale includes two subscales: positive emotions and negative emotions.

In order to assess whether our proposed dimensions represent approach/avoidance and control/dyscontrol, we will use the BIS/BAS Scale (Carver and White, 2013) and the Brief Self-Control Scale (Tangney, Baumeister, and Boone, 2004) as anchoring scales.

The BIS/BAS scale is a 24-item measure that uses a 4-point scale ranging from 1 (very true for me) to 4 (very false for me) to measure two motivational systems, the behavioral inhibition system (BIS) and the behavioral activation system (BAS). The BIS corresponds to motivation to avoid aversive outcomes, and the BAS corresponds to motivation to approach goal-oriented outcomes.

The Brief Self-Control Scale is a 13-item measure that uses a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (Not at all like me) to 5 (very much like me) to assess dispositional self-regulatory behaviors.
registration_responses.q18.question:
The mean of each trait response to emotion scale (i.e., ispative mean imputation) for each scale will be converted to a z score. Scales with more than 50% missing items will be considered missing for that person and not subject to further analysis. A general propensity to response to emotion will be assessed by examining item-total correlations and the mean correlation among the measures, and if there is evidence for a general propensity (majority of item-total correlations greater than .30), then the z scores will be summed. 

Dimension scores will be created by weighting z scores for each measure of response to emotion by its value on that dimension and summing. Anchoring scales will not be included in the dimension scores.
registration_responses.q19.question:
1.	Hypothesis 1 states that two dimensions (approach/avoidance and control/dyscontrol) will characterize the factor structure of trait responses to emotion. The multidimensional model will be constructed using ALSCAL in SPSS. Distances among emotion trait response measures and anchoring scales will be calculated as 1 minus the correlation between each pair of measures and treated as interval data. There are 19 total emotion trait response measures (including subscales), allowing up to 4-dimensional models (Kruskal and Wish, 1978). Stress statistics will be examined for 1- through 4-dimensional models, and the highest-dimensional model that yields a substantive reduction in stress (greater than or equal to .05) will be adopted. The position of anchoring scales (e.g., BIS/BAS Scales and the Brief Self-Control Scale) will be used to determine whether dimensions represent approach/avoidance and control; that is, if an anchoring scale lies along the dimension rather than in interstitial space, its construct will provide interpretation of the scale.

2.	Hypothesis 2 states that individuals who are younger and are female will utilize more approach trait emotion responses; in contrast, individuals who are older and are male will utilize more avoidant trait emotion responses. Additionally, individuals who are older and are female (particularly in regard to negative emotions) will utilize more control trait emotion responses than individuals who are younger and are male (particularly in regard to negative emotions).

The relationships among these demographic variables and the dimension scores will be investigated using both zero-order correlations and multiple regression models. Multiple regression models will allow for us to model the relationships between the demographic variables and the dimension scores by fitting a linear equation to observed data. Every demographic variable will serve as an independent variable, and the dimension score will be the dependent variable. The demographic variables’ relationship with the dimension score will be calculated while holding the other demographic variables constant using the following equation: (dimension score) = B_0 + B_1X_((age)) + B_2X_((gender)) where β0 = the predicted value of the dimension score when all demographic variables are held constant, and β_iX = the regression coefficient (or slope) for an independent variable. To determine statistical significance, alpha will be set at p is less than .05. The Benjamini-Hochberg procedure, a sequential approach that is equivalent to Bonferroni correction but has been demonstrated to yield greater power (Benjamini and Hochberg, 1995; Thissen, Steinberg, Kuang, 2002), will be applied to account for performing multiple tests on each proposed trait response to emotion dimension to reduce our Type I error rate.

attributes.title: THE EFFECT OF NON-SURGICAL PERIODONTAL TREATMENT IN SYSTEMIC BLOOD PRESSURE: SYSTEMATIC REVIEW AND META-ANALYSIS

q1.value: THE EFFECT OF NON-SURGICAL PERIODONTAL TREATMENT IN SYSTEMIC BLOOD PRESSURE: SYSTEMATIC REVIEW AND META-ANALYSIS

q3.value: The authors will perform a systematic search by using PubMed (MEDLINE), Cochrane Library, Web of Science, BVS Bireme and OpenGrey databases including only randomized clinical trials of patients with periodontitis who had non-surgical periodontal treatment and blood pressure measurement. Excluding criteria consisted of metabolic conditions that could alter the course of the disease, such as arthritis and diabetes mellitus.

q4.value: Does non-surgical periodontal therapy have a significant effect on blood pressure reduction?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value:
The present systematic review and meta-analysis aims to evaluate the effect of non-surgical periodontal treatment on systemic arterial blood pressure in patients with periodontitis.
The authors will perform a systematic search by using PubMed (MEDLINE), Cochrane Library, Web of Science, BVS Bireme and OpenGrey databases including only randomized clinical trials of patients with periodontitis who had non-surgical periodontal treatment and blood pressure measurement. Excluding criteria consisted of metabolic conditions that could alter the course of the disease, such as arthritis and diabetes mellitus.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The methodology of the present systematic review was conducted based on the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions, version 5.1.0 (HIGGINS & GREEN, 2011), and written as the guidelines of PRISMA statement (MOHER et al., 2009).
The question and the objectives of the study were established according to PICO strategy (acronym for Participants, Intervention, Comparison and Outcome) (MOHER et al., 2009) to evaluate the influence of periodontal treatment on systemic blood pressure (C) considering whether non-surgical periodontal treatment (I) in patients with chronic periodontitis (P) reduces blood pressure (O) in these patients.
Screening and selection:
The inclusion criteria were randomized clinical trials that had performed periodontal treatment in patients with chronic periodontitis and had measured systemic blood pressure (SBP and DBP) prior to and after non-surgical periodontal treatment. Another criteria was that the study selected should present a control group with no periodontal treatment. Criteria for periodontal diagnosis were based on periodontal probing depth (PD) and clinical attachment level (CAL).
Exclusion criteria were studies in animal model, studies that included diabetic or metabolic syndrome patients, patients with arthritis, studies using systemic antibiotics, and longitudinal studies that were not RCTs, case control, cohorts, case reports, cross-sectional studies and in languages other than Portuguese and English.
The Cochrane Collaboration’s tool for assessing risk of bias was used to evaluate methodological quality of selected articles (HIGGINS & GREEN, 2011; MOHER et al., 2009). In this quality assessment, selection bias (random sequence generation and allocation concealment), performance bias (blindness of participants and professionals), detection bias (blinding of outcome assessment), attrition bias (incomplete outcome data), reporting bias (selective outcome report), and other sources of bias were considered. Following the evaluations of each of these biases, the classification in high risk, low risk or uncertain risk was established, according to the Cochrane tool (HIGGINS & GREEN, 2011)
After the quality evaluation, the studies classified as low risk had the data and standard deviations of systolic and diastolic blood pressure extracted and organized according to follow-up times.

q13.value: Initial database searches resulted in 3399 titles

question.value: Blood pressure

The results of mean differences for systolic and diastolic blood pressure were combined for meta-analysis using statistical software (STATA® 10.0) and reported with a 95% confidence interval. The X2 tests for heterogeneity and the I2 test for variation in the summary measure attributable to heterogeneity were performed and the random effects model was used. The random effect method was used to combine the study estimates, which assumes that the studies have different (underlying) effect sizes and take into account the additional variation implied in making this assumption. We also adopted a strategy of using strict inclusion criteria to investigate the characteristics of the study, leading to a less biased meta-analysis with reduced heterogeneity.

The present systematic review and meta-analysis aims to evaluate the effect of non-surgical periodontal treatment on systemic arterial blood pressure in patients with periodontitis.
The authors will perform a systematic search by using PubMed (MEDLINE), Cochrane Library, Web of Science, BVS Bireme and OpenGrey databases including only randomized clinical trials of patients with periodontitis who had non-surgical periodontal treatment and blood pressure measurement. registration_responses.q12.question:
The methodology of the present systematic review was conducted based on the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions, version 5.1.0 (HIGGINS & GREEN, 2011), and written as the guidelines of PRISMA statement (MOHER et al., 2009).
The question and the objectives of the study were established according to PICO strategy (acronym for Participants, Intervention, Comparison and Outcome) (MOHER et al., 2009) to evaluate the influence of periodontal treatment on systemic blood pressure (C) considering whether non-surgical periodontal treatment (I) in patients with chronic periodontitis (P) reduces blood pressure (O) in these patients.
Screening and selection:
