attributes.title: A Perfect Match? How Job Demands Shape Gender and Racial Discrimination in Hiring

q1.value: A Perfect Match? How Job Demands Shape Gender and Racial Discrimination in Hiring

q2.value: Katherine Weisshaar, Koji Chavez, Tania Cabello-Hutt

q3.value: In this project we ask: how and to what extent do gender and racial discrimination job applicants experience vary across job demands? Are employers more likely to discriminate against women or Black applicants when they do not meet a job’s required demands – for example, required experience or skills? When the job demands are abstract or concrete? When the job demands are masculine or feminine-typed? Using a field experiment (audit correspondence study), we propose to address these questions across four occupational contexts – accountants, human resource professionals, sales professionals, and software engineers – that differ in female representation (high, low) and task orientation (interpersonal, technical).

q4.value:
We will test multiple competing hypotheses with this project. 
1. With respect to overall callback rates, we predict that fictitious Black men, White women, and Black women will experience lower callback rates than White men, all else equal. We expect that the direction and magnitude of discrimination may be different across occupation: for example, in more feminized occupations, employers may prefer women over men.
2. We will test competing hypotheses as to whether meeting job requirements (being qualified) compared to applicants' over- or under-qualification has an effect on discrimination levels. We will test hypotheses that suggest that either (2a) qualification does not affect discrimination by gender and race; (2b) underqualification amplifies discrimination, with perfect qualification or over-qualification reducing discrimination; (2c) both under- and over-qualification amplifies discrimination; (2d) there is a curvilinear effect of qualification on discrimination, with some levels of over- or under-qualification widening discrimination and some reducing.
3. We predict that masculine- or feminine-typed job demands may affect discrimination either through men being advantaged in masculine contexts and women in feminine-contexts (3a) or specific types of masculine- and feminine demands (e.g. agency, technical competence) having differing effects by gender and race on discrimination levels (3b).
4. We predict that vague job demands, compared to concrete demands, may be associated with higher levels of discrimination.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will field an audit correspondence study on 4 occupations (accountants, human resources professionals, sales professionals, and software engineers), with a total of about 12,000 job applications submitted (3,000 per occupation). The resumes will be randomly assigned a male or female name, to be interpreted as Black or White. Resumes will also be randomly assigned a number of skills and years of experience, so that the match between the applicant's skills and the job requirements varies across the sample. Jobs will be selected from a large online job listing site, and randomly sampled for inclusion in the audit. We will submit resumes (typically two per job, 1 day apart), with the name, applicant skills, and resume template randomly assigned. We will record callbacks (employers' request for an interview or further information). We will additionally save the job listing information to analyze the job's required skills, and merge the job listings with data from Burning Glass Technologies on skills and associations of skills. We will then analyze how callbacks vary as a function of the the applicant's perceived gender/race and the job demands - the match between the applicant's skills and those required, the masculine/feminine-typing of skills, and how vague or concrete the skills are.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: We have fielded a pilot study of accountants in 2019 and basic analyses have been conducted for the purposes of submitting grant applications.

question.value: As described above, we will randomly sample online job listings for each of the occupations in our study, and randomly assign resume characteristics for applications to the sampled jobs. The data collection will be conducted from June 2020 through December 2021.

q13.value: The sample size is estimated to be 12,000 job applications or 3,000 per occupation.

question.value: We will manipulate the applicant's perceived gender and race, signaled by name, and other characteristics on the resume including common skills in the occupation.

The outcome variable will be the callbacks. We will measure both requests for interviews and additional information. 
To measure variables associated with job demands, we will merge the job listings with Burning Glass Technologies (BGT) data. This will allow us to identify and categorize individual job demands. We will use computational text analysis techniques to characterize job demands as masculine, feminine, or both. We will also create two measures associated with how vague or concrete a job demand is: first based on whether the demand represents an underlying applicant characteristic rather than a technical or specific skill, and second based on whether the demand is preferred or recommended vs. required. We will test and create multiple measures of the applicant's match with the job demands, including the total number of skills the applicant meets, the proportion of overlapping skills, and the number of skills the applicant possesses beyond those required.
We plan to analyze data using logit or probit regression models, predicting callbacks, interacting perceived gender/race with the job demand variables.

attributes.title: Conversations About Cost in the Clinic: The Physician’s Perspective

q1.value: Conversations About Cost in the Clinic: The Physician’s Perspective

q3.value:
The cost of health care in the United States has risen significantly over the last 15 years. A number of interventions and policies have been put into place to address the financial toxicity associated with these high costs, including Medicare low-income subsidies, drug rebates, and pharmaceutical patient assistance programs. Physician experts and patient advocacy groups have also increasingly urged physicians to discuss out-of-pocket costs with their patients. These conversations can lead to changes in prescription patterns that are tailored to patients’ clinical and financial priorities and can connect patients with financial counselors and other ancillary staff with detailed knowledge of health insurance plans. Physicians’ current attitudes toward cost conversations, and their basic knowledge of insurance terminology, are largely unknown. A better understanding of these subjects will help direct efforts toward increasing the frequency and efficacy of patient-physician cost conversations, and thus improve patient access to financial assistance and financial wellbeing.

The objectives of this study are twofold:
Objective 1: Assess physicians’ attitudes toward and experiences with engaging in cost conversations with patients.
Objective 2: Assess physicians’ knowledge of terminology relevant to understanding health insurance coverage in order to determine how well-equipped they are to lead productive cost conversations with their patients.

Word versions of the preregistration and data entry protocol have been attached to the Design Plan section of

q4.value:
Primary hypothesis: Subspecialists (gastroenterologists and rheumatologists) score higher on the knowledge portion of the survey than primary care physicians.

Secondary hypotheses
Knowledge score is not associated with attitudes toward cost conversations.
Physicians with more experience (more years since medical school graduation) score higher on the knowledge portion of the survey.
Physicians who do not work in an academic medical center or teaching hospital score higher on the knowledge portion of the survey. 
Physicians with higher proportion of private / Medicare patients score higher on the knowledge portion of the survey.
Physicians who have access to a social worker or financial counselor score higher on the knowledge portion of the survey.
Physicians who use an electronic health record (EHR) do not report more comfort discussing out-of-pocket costs with their patients.
EHR has not enabled physicians to have more informed conversations about costs.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cross-sectional observational study. An anonymous, national mail-in survey developed by the research team will be distributed to a random sample of US practicing physicians. The sample will consist of 300 randomly selected physicians from each of three specialties, for a total of 900 randomly selected physicians. The specialties are: Primary Care (Family Medicine and Internal Medicine), Gastroenterology, and Rheumatology.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: As of the date of submission of this research plan for preregistration, the data from our final survey have not yet been observed or recorded. We do have preliminary data from two pilot studies, consisting of 300 surveys each. We plan to use the results of surveys in the second pilot study that were sent to primary care physicians, rheumatologists and gastroenterologists. See below for details about the pilot study.

question.value:
The final, anonymous, national mail-in survey developed by our research team will be distributed to a random sample of 750 US physicians practicing in three specialties. The mailing list for this survey of US practicing physicians will be sourced from an American Medical Association authorized database licensee (Redi-Data). 

Inclusion criteria: 
Specialties: Primary Care (Family Medicine and Internal Medicine), Gastroenterology, and Rheumatology.
Office-based physicians

Exclusion criteria
Medical residents
Veterans Administration
Indian Health Service
Physicians reporting 0% clinical effort or who are no longer practicing

Subjects will each be mailed an envelope containing:
A cover letter that will describe study objectives and request that physicians complete a survey about their experiences discussing out-of-pocket medical costs and insurance coverage with their patients.
A 3-page survey 
A self-addressed, stamped envelope
A self-addressed, stamped postcard 
$5 as compensation (only in the first wave of mailings), with a request to return the money if the survey is not completed
A pen

Timeline: We mailed out 300 surveys in May 2019, as a pilot. The surveys were sent to 50 physicians each from one of six subspecialties that included Primary Care, Gastroenterology, and Rheumatology. Based on the findings from the pilot, we made modifications to the cover letter and the survey. We will exclude the results of the first pilot, due to these modifications. We mailed out another 300 surveys in August 2019, as a second pilot. The surveys were again sent to 50 physicians each from one of six subspecialties: Primary Care, Gastroenterology, Rheumatology, Orthopedic Surgery, General Surgery, and Pediatrics. Based on the results of this pilot, we have mailed out the same survey and cover letter to 750 physicians practicing in three of the above subspecialties: Primary Care, Gastroenterology, and Rheumatology. A second wave of surveys will be mailed out to physicians who did not respond in the first wave, likely in February 2019. We will include the results of the portion of the second pilot survey that was sent to primary care physicians, gastroenterologists and rheumatologists in our final results. 

Survey: Completion of the survey questionnaire will take participants approximately 8-10 minutes. Physicians who choose to participate in the study will return the survey in an enclosed self-addressed, stamped envelope. The surveys that are returned to the research team will be anonymous: no names or other identifying information will be collected via the questionnaire, so it will not be possible to link subjects to their survey responses. Surveys will be mailed to a Duke mailbox, and secured using double-lock storage. Only members of the research team will have access to these data. 

Postcard: Physicians will have the option to mail back an enclosed postcard indicating that they do not wish to receive another survey from the research team, regardless of their completion of the survey. Each postcard will be marked with a randomized subject identification code that will be linked to participant information. Physicians will be instructed to mail the postcard separately from the survey. Separate returns of the postcard and the survey will allow us to: 1) use the subject identification codes on the postcards to mark off which physicians do not want to receive a survey in the second wave of mailings; 2) maintain the anonymity of survey responses, since survey responses will not contain any identifying information, and will be received separately from the postcards.

q13.value: 900 US practicing physicians (150 from pilot #2 and 750 from the final survey).

q14.value: This number was chosen based on the amount of funding available. No power calculations were made.

question.value:
Response rate
Proportion of responses received from the 1st vs 2nd wave of surveys

Physician attitudes toward cost conversations, measured via a 6-point Likert scale that ranges from “strongly disagree” to “strongly agree.”
There is nothing I can do to lower patients’ out-of-pocket costs.
Doctors have an obligation to initiate discussions about out-of-pocket costs when writing orders.
I know approximately how much my patients are spending on their medical care.
It is not my job to deal with patients’ out-of-pocket costs.
My patients expect me to solve their cost-related issues during or right after clinic visits.
I have a hard time advising my patients on their out-of-pocket costs.
I feel uncomfortable discussing out-of-pocket costs with my patients.
I do not have enough time to discuss patients’ out-of-pocket costs.
I usually don’t know how to answer questions about out-of-pocket costs.

Knowledge: Physician ability to read a vignette and demonstrate understanding of deductibles, coinsurance, copay, out-of-pocket maximums, drug tiers. 
If any survey responses in this section of the survey are wrong due to presumed misunderstanding of the question (e.g. the respondent adds up premium + copay when copay is all that was needed), we will perform a sensitivity analysis in which we count these responses as correct. 
If a respondent answers some of the questions in this section but not all, we will count the non-responses as “I don’t know.”

Demographic characteristics
Subspecialty: primary care, rheumatology, gastroenterology
Gender
Ethnicity
Race
Age
Years since medical school graduation
Proportion of time spent in outpatient care, inpatient care, and other
Proportion of patients covered by various types of insurance
Presence of an academic affiliation
Presence of a social worker or financial counselor in the clinic
Presence of an electronic health record in the clinic
Utility of the electronic health record
Electronic health record’s ability to provide out-of-pocket cost information

Knowledge score: We will create a continuous variable calculated as number of correct knowledge answers divided by total number of knowledge questions. 

Attitude domains: We will perform factor analysis of responses to attitude questions to determine whether any questions are strongly correlated. If they are, we will lump them together into attitude domains. We will use a threshold for pairwise correlation of >0.8.

The majority of our results will be descriptive. 

Primary analysis: Statistical analysis will be performed using ordinary least squares (OLS) regression to compare knowledge scores between subspecialists (rheumatologists and gastroenterologists combined) and primary care physicians (family medicine physicians and general internists combined). We will include demographic data and attitude domains (see “variables” above) in the regression as covariates. We will perform statistical tests to determine whether the dependent variable should be log transformed and to test for violation of OLS assumptions, including multicollinearity, homoscedasticity, and normality. 

Secondary analyses: We will test for all of the secondary hypotheses listed in the “study information” section using OLS regression. 

We may perform additional exploratory analyses.

q21.value: Statistical significance will be defined as p<0.05. We will perform Bonferroni adjustment to correct for multiple comparisons in our secondary and exploratory analyses.

q22.value:
We will exclude the following samples from our descriptive analyses:
Completely blank surveys
Physicians who report 100% inpatient clinical time
Physicians practicing exclusively in a Veterans Administration setting
Physicians practicing exclusively in an Indian Health Service setting
Physicians reporting 0% clinical effort or who are no longer practicing

We will exclude the following samples from our knowledge score analysis: No responses to any knowledge questions.

q23.value: In the Results section of our paper, we will describe how many samples had missing data in each of the survey categories (attitude, knowledge, covariates).

q24.value: We will explore any associations between covariates not mentioned in Section 4 (hypotheses) and knowledge score. We will also explore any associations between covariates and various attitudes toward cost conversations.

q25.value:
We will perform the following sensitivity analyses:
1) Count responses that are wrong due to presumed misunderstanding of the question (e.g. the respondent adds up premium + copay when copay is all that was needed) as correct. 
2) Count all surveys, including those excluded as described above.

Based on the results of this pilot, we have mailed out the same survey and cover letter to 750 physicians practicing in three of the above subspecialties: Primary Care, Gastroenterology, and Rheumatology. A second wave of surveys will be mailed out to physicians who did not respond in the first wave, likely in February 2019. We will include the results of the portion of the second pilot survey that was sent to primary care physicians, gastroenterologists and rheumatologists in our final results. 

Survey: Completion of the survey questionnaire will take participants approximately 8-10 minutes. Physicians who choose to participate in the study will return the survey in an enclosed self-addressed, stamped envelope. The surveys that are returned to the research team will be anonymous: no names or other identifying information will be collected via the questionnaire, so it will not be possible to link subjects to their survey responses. Surveys will be mailed to a Duke mailbox, and secured using double-lock storage. Only members of the research team will have access to these data. 

Postcard: Physicians will have the option to mail back an enclosed postcard indicating that they do not wish to receive another survey from the research team, regardless of their completion of the survey. Each postcard will be marked with a randomized subject identification code that will be linked to participant information. Physicians will be instructed to mail the postcard separately from the survey. Separate returns of the postcard and the survey will allow us to: 1) use the subject identification codes on the postcards to mark off which physicians do not want to receive a survey in the second wave of mailings; 2) maintain the anonymity of survey responses, since survey responses will not contain any identifying information, and will be received separately from the postcards.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Response rate
Proportion of responses received from the 1st vs 2nd wave of surveys

Physician attitudes toward cost conversations, measured via a 6-point Likert scale that ranges from “strongly disagree” to “strongly agree.”
There is nothing I can do to lower patients’ out-of-pocket costs.
Doctors have an obligation to initiate discussions about out-of-pocket costs when writing orders.
I know approximately how much my patients are spending on their medical care.
It is not my job to deal with patients’ out-of-pocket costs.
My patients expect me to solve their cost-related issues during or right after clinic visits.
I have a hard time advising my patients on their out-of-pocket costs.
I feel uncomfortable discussing out-of-pocket costs with my patients.
I do not have enough time to discuss patients’ out-of-pocket costs.
I usually don’t know how to answer questions about out-of-pocket costs.

Knowledge: Physician ability to read a vignette and demonstrate understanding of deductibles, coinsurance, copay, out-of-pocket maximums, drug tiers. 
If any survey responses in this section of the survey are wrong due to presumed misunderstanding of the question (e.g. the respondent adds up premium + copay when copay is all that was needed), we will perform a sensitivity analysis in which we count these responses as correct. 
If a respondent answers some of the questions in this section but not all, we will count the non-responses as “I don’t know.”

Demographic characteristics
Subspecialty: primary care, rheumatology, gastroenterology
Gender
Ethnicity
Race
Age
Years since medical school graduation
Proportion of time spent in outpatient care, inpatient care, and other
Proportion of patients covered by various types of insurance
Presence of an academic affiliation
Presence of a social worker or financial counselor in the clinic
Presence of an electronic health record in the clinic
Utility of the electronic health record
Electronic health record’s ability to provide out-of-pocket cost information
registration_responses.q18.question:
Knowledge score: We will create a continuous variable calculated as number of correct knowledge answers divided by total number of knowledge questions. 

Attitude domains: We will perform factor analysis of responses to attitude questions to determine whether any questions are strongly correlated. If they are, we will lump them together into attitude domains. We will use a threshold for pairwise correlation of >0.8.
registration_responses.q19.question:
The majority of our results will be descriptive. 

Primary analysis: Statistical analysis will be performed using ordinary least squares (OLS) regression to compare knowledge scores between subspecialists (rheumatologists and gastroenterologists combined) and primary care physicians (family medicine physicians and general internists combined). We will include demographic data and attitude domains (see “variables” above) in the regression as covariates. We will perform statistical tests to determine whether the dependent variable should be log transformed and to test for violation of OLS assumptions, including multicollinearity, homoscedasticity, and normality. 

Secondary analyses: We will test for all of the secondary hypotheses listed in the “study information” section using OLS regression. 

We may perform additional exploratory analyses.
